Title: Pregnancy and the Human Brain: A Window of Neuroplasticity

Pregnancy is a transformative period of significant neuroplasticity, with long-lasting changes in brain structure and function. Despite its importance, the neural mechanisms underlying this critical period of development remain poorly understood. This prospective cohort study aims to comprehensively map changes in brain anatomy and function across pregnancy and the postpartum period, pinpoint key factors driving pregnancy-related neuroplasticity, and reveal the neural substrates for potential adaptive and maladaptive processes.

Focusing on maternal caregiving, mental health disorders, and memory issues, this project will employ cutting-edge neuroimaging, psychopedagogic measures, and biomedical measures to track women from before conception through the postpartum period. By elucidating the neural mechanisms underlying pregnancy-related neuroplasticity, this study has the potential to establish a foundation for an emerging field of human neuroscience.

The proposed research may yield critical insights into the neurobiological journey to motherhood, informing strategies for promoting healthy maternal brain development and mitigating the risk of mental health disorders and memory issues. Furthermore, this study may provide a novel framework for understanding the complex interplay between brain development, maternal caregiving, and offspring outcomes. Ultimately, this project has the potential to transform our understanding of the maternal brain and its critical role in shaping the next generation.

By elucidating the neural mechanisms underlying pregnancy-related neuroplasticity, we may uncover novel targets for interventions aimed at promoting healthy brain development and mitigating the risk of mental health disorders in mothers. Ultimately, this research may inform the development of evidence-based strategies to support women's mental and brain health during this critical life stage.
